data.title: Camel case it!
data.statement:
The year is 2045, and code has officially become law, so much so that natural language is to be formatted as variable names. After a long debate, it was officially decided that camelCase should be used to format sentences, and that existing literature must be converted to this new formatting.

As a software engineer, you are called in to produce a tool able to convert some text from legacy literature to camelCased literature.

Additional constraints are the following:

- <<Existing case within words is dropped.>> For example, "StartTLS" becomes "starttls".
- <<Apostrophes ({{'}}) are dropped.>> For example, "can't do" becomes "cantDo".
- <<Hyphens ({{-}}) are considered the same as spaces.>> For example, "rendez-vous" becomes "rendezVous".
- <<Other punctuation ({{.}}, {{,}}, {{?}}) and spaces around them must be kept, and separates the different sequences of words that are "camelCased" together.>> For example, "Hello, beautiful world." becomes "hello, beautifulWorld.".

testCases.title: Simple sentence
testCases.testIn: The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.

testCases.title: Simple sentence
testCases.testIn: Pack my box with five dozen liquor jugs.

testCases.title: Apostrophes and other punctuation
testCases.testIn: Beautiful weather today, don't you think?

testCases.title: Apostrophes and other punctuation
testCases.testIn: We're feeling unwell today, may we take the day off?

testCases.title: Hyphens and uppercase
testCases.testIn: Mozilla Firefox is a non-profit maintained HTTP browser for Windows, macOS and Linux.

testCases.title: Hyphens and uppercase
testCases.testIn: StartTLS is a mechanism for establishing encryption on already-established connections, standardized by the IETF.

testCases.title: It's not Shakespeare!
testCases.testIn: O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name. Or if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love and I'll no longer be a Capulet.
testCases.testOut: oRomeo, romeo, whereforeArtThouRomeo? denyThyFatherAndRefuseThyName. orIfThouWiltNot, beButSwornMyLoveAndIllNoLongerBeACapulet.

testCases.title: It's not Shakespeare!
testCases.testIn: To be, or not to be, that is the question. Whether it is nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles and by opposing end them.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The year is 2045, and code has officially become law, so much so that natural language is to be formatted as variable names. After a long debate, it was officially decided that camelCase should be used to format sentences, and that existing literature must be converted to this new formatting.

As a software engineer, you are called in to produce a tool able to convert some text from legacy literature to camelCased literature.

Additional constraints are the following:

- Existing case within words is dropped. For example, "StartTLS" becomes "starttls".
- Apostrophes (') are dropped. For example, "can't do" becomes "cantDo".
- Hyphens (-) are considered the same as spaces. For example, "rendez-vous" becomes "rendezVous".
- Other punctuation (., ,, ?) and spaces around them must be kept, and separates the different sequences of words that are "camelCased" together. For example, "Hello, beautiful world." becomes "hello, beautifulWorld.".
Input
First line: A text to convert.
Output
First line: The converted text.
Constraints
1 <= length(text) < 256
Example
Input
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
Output
theQuickBrownFoxJumpsOverTheLazyDog.
